Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 02:53PM Isabella4 wrote: Bimmer. Do you own your property ?? We have what is called equity release over here in UK. Basically it means you can take a big chunk out of the value of the property right now, and use it to help out with whatever, so, at the end of the day when the property passes to whoever it is being left to there will be the 'big chunk' already taken to take off the value of the estate. OK, so the kids or relatives don't get what they are expecting, but at the moment its your money to use as you need. I do not believe in working all your life just to give the kids financial security when you're gone. I know if we run out of cash we will without a doubt release cash from our property. I am not aiming to live in poverty just so my kids can fly out and buy new houses and cars when I'm gone !! Best wishes to you and Diane.  Isabella.
Posts.Title: Something else we all have to deal with. Bimmer AliceJean

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2009 03:42PM Isabella4 wrote: Disgusting self centered people like your SIL don't deserve a minute spent on them....one day it may be them and then just go ahead and ignore. I haven't heard from 2 of my brothers since the day I rang to tell them of my bc, a third brother rang me once just after my bilat, six years ago, and my only sister ( younger than me ) never came near me to help, and they all live in the same town as me ! I really feel it badly, just no contact from any of them from what was 6 years ago, a close, regularly visiting, family. It really upsets me, mainly at birthdays, seeing what used to be a shelf of birthday cards, to just ...nothing. They have no idea if I am dead or alive, and it hurts but I have to admit that by now they don't care. All I did was to get breast cancer. My regret is that I, being the eldest, and living on a farm, always had them all over for Christmas and all the main holidays. The whole flippin' gang, and all their kids and in laws as well. I wish I had taken them all out in a boat and slung them overboard !!!!    Nasty??  Hell, yes. Isabella.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 07:05PM Isabella4 wrote: I was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia 2/3 years before bc. The pains, as you describe, were very much like I was getting. The main bones that drove me mad were my thigh bones and my humerus, almost as bad as toothache. Also lots of pain in my hips and sternum, but more of a 'sore' pain here. It took about 3 years to correctly diagnose me, I was passed from doc to doc, and felt all were thinking I was laying it on !! If only ! I had to get to a rheumatologist in the end for a diagnosis, and the main way to diagnose, well, you'll know this, if you've had the test, is to find about a dozen (I think) points on my head and neck that were sore. I never realised they WERE sore until I was prodded by the doc, so I don't know.  I know I have something, and it helps to have a name, then people don't think you're mad. I even had a trip to see a psychiatrist to see 'if something was bothering me to cause the pain' what a SHOWER docs can be sometimes.  Good Luck with your scan. Isabella.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 11:24AM Isabella4 wrote: I'm five and a half years out from double mast., and for the last year I have had itching along my scar, on the' bad' side, under my arm only. Under my arm its pretty well numb, but I have a tiny scar from a drain up under my arm, and that too itches. (this little scar is still ever so slightly open, and weeps a little, only a very little,now and then. My drain was in about 5 months, just would not stop running, so it seems that it didn't heal up completely.) I too have to get out my bristle brush...its the only thing that eases the area. I got this from DD who had severe itching in the latter part of her last pregnancy....she wouldn't go anywhere without her brush, but mine is nowhere as bad as that. Isabella.

Posts.Title: Got Excellent News Today!!!! LuAnnH Calico

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 12:37AM Isabella4 wrote: Cheryl. I am so sorry to hear of your loss. Dogs mean the world to me, more than most people !!! I have a lot of dogs, and find it very hard to have a favorite, because petting one more than any of the others causes havoc. I had a family turn up at my door one day, they'd heard I loved dogs. They told me I was their last resort, if I didn't take Max, the next stop was the vet, and they wouldn't be bringing him home. Out jumps this great big Rotweiller, looking just evil ! I am used to small dogs, so this was new territory. Over the weeks we became firm friends, he made me get up and walk him, and I got to like walking!I had him 9 years. Twice he had one of my little dogs in his mouth, he hated small dogs, he just one day managed to get over the fence from 'his' garden, into where my Pekingeses were, and just got hold of one by the scruff of his neck, and had him hanging lifeless. I yelled and screamed for DH to come,I just could not open Max's jaws, luckily he heard me, and managed to prise the mouth open, release the Peke, who came to in a couple of minutes. Next time he had a Yorkie dog in the same situation, again DH managed to release, and he was Ok. Then I just dare not let Max run around again, DH concreted a pen for him,and I felt like a prison guard, but we had small g/kids, and Max didn't like kids either !! I just loved that dog, he had two goes at me growling and showing his teeth over the years,I had to hit him on the head with a coal shovel once,I can laugh now, but at the time he had me pinned up against a wall, and he weighed just over 11 stones, and in those days I was 9 stone wet thru ! Max got cancer, and I kept him at home with me, on strong drugs until the end, I was just heartbroken when he died. This was 4 years ago. I buried him in 'his' garden, and planted an Oak tree right on top of him,its about 15 feet high now, and I often walk down my garden to the Oak, and to be with Max.  Since his death I bought myself 2 more Rotweiller boys, they are18 months now, and hard work. I haven't the energy to walk them so we have extended their run, and let them out when the little dogs are all away. So I know just what you are feeling. My sister says to me 'why do you keep on keeping dogs, when they just go die on you' She had 1dog and 1 cat and said never again she couldn't stand it.I just cannot live without my dogs, so thats why I do it ! So if you're a true dog lover you'll get another one to love. Good Luck with the scans. Isabella.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 06:52PM Isabella4 wrote: I had a problem with my drains, the 1st came out at 3  days, was about 20" , really freaked me to see this, although I felt nothing. Second drain just wouldn't dry up, and the stitch that was holding it onto my side drove me nutty. I got DH to cut the stitch, and pull it out for me...oooooo, the relief !! I had my second drain in 12 weeks, unbelievable I know, but it just didn't slow up. By the time it came to be pulled, it couldn't be done, it'd grown in. I made an almighty fuss in the Drs room, as 3 of them tried to pull it out, in the end I jumped out of the chair and told them to leave me alone. I had to have a general anaesthetic to get it out a week later. Deedee. The stringy blood is quite normal, its amazing what does come down these drains. You should be soon getting rid of your drain if you're 4 days post lumpectomy. Welcome to you. Isabella.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2010 03:36PM Isabella4 wrote: Hi. I have Fibromyalgia. Was about 4 or 5 years complaining about pain before I was referred to specialist, he said quite quickly it was Fibro, then said there's nothing much we can do for it !! I took some muscle relaxing drug, but it didn't even register, so after a few months I gave it up. I have tried various group, and one to one activities, but all were a waste of time, and had just nicely gotten used to living with it when bc hit ! My Fibro specialist was leaning towards Fibro being caused by chemicals I used to handle, well before we were told to wear protective clothing, and we were just getting into doing some investigations when I started bc treatment, and all these investigations went out of the window ! I have never really bothered going back and starting up investigations, have had a belly full of hospitals, and now try and avoid them if I can. There are a handful of other girls who have Fibro on these boards. Isabella.

Thinking of you, and wishing peace for you and Diane in the next few days. Take care, Isabella.

Posts.Title: Mrs_X_Sunneedazee (Amber) dmacw janie44

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2012 05:00PM Isabella4 wrote: Hey, just found this topic. Another FM patient here, have had 'something' for about 25-28 years...was labelled ME, then Chronic Fatigue, then after ruling out Lyme disease and Lupus, had another batch of testing and was told it was FM about 12 or so years ago....was dx'd with BC 9 years ago. The medics have been terrible, very disbelieving, and generally unhelpful. After all there's not often anything to 'see,' just a whining woman going on and on about wanting some pain relief ! When I was dx'd with BC, after the first shock of things I almost felt some sort of relief that I would be believed, at long last,when I visited my GP. Like you, barbe I sometimes have awful flares, and am ultra sensitive to touch....but what to do ?? We only have one life, one go at things, so we make the most of what we can when we can ! If anything I am a lot worse than I was 10 years ago, but can manage it a bit easier nowadays....realise it isn't going to kill me, well, not at the moment! so I live with it.  Isabella.
Posts.Title: anyone out there with auto-immune/chronic pain issues before dx? jessamine SuzyBlue

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 05:36PM Isabella4 wrote: Oh I forgot, I had a bit of a car smash ( NOT my fault!) a while ago, like 20 years, that caused no end of problems ...cervical spondylosis mainly. All one side was quite affected , my neck, RHS ribs, arm, hip and right down to my toes...AGAIN something you couldn't SEE...and again got the disbelieving treatment from my GP. Even when I got a 'label' put on the condition by a specialist, my GP actually wrote, in her notes, (which I asked my solicitor to request, he could make the request formally, I couldn't ) that she thought 'there was a psyche element in all this somewhere'. I could have murdered her when I saw that, as NO WAY can I have it taken from my record, it's there forever, and could have a bearing on how other doctors treat me. I think if I'd just sat down and put up with all the pain, and not asked for referrals to various specialists to try and get  to the bottom of all the pain I was in,  she would never have written this. Only good thing about that Dr is that she has retired now. I know the above isn't an autoimmune disease, but it WAS , and still can be to some extent, a chronic pain issue. Isabella.
Posts.Title: anyone out there with auto-immune/chronic pain issues before dx? jessamine SuzyBlue

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2007 08:07AM Isabella4 wrote: Sue. I am also in UK and I find you MUST make yourself heard. Our NHS system is lacking to say the least. I was not prepared to just be a number, so I started to make a fuss, and stand up for myself. Don't alienate your medical team, rather educate yourself and have questions ready to fire at them, and don't take no for an answer. Make notes on what you want to know, and don't be rushed out of your appointment until you have answers. Have you been given a breast care nurse? I found mine could get into the system, and give me results long before my appointment was due, which cut down on my worrying, and got answers for me. If you have a bc nurse lean on her, she will be able to get you quickly to a psychologist, trained to help bc patients. (I was seeing a psychologist within a month of having my mastectomy, and it DID help)  Things today are much better than they were 20 years ago, we have moved on, and treatments are so much more advanced. Good luck, things will get into order for you, sooner than you think. Isabella.
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 11:28AM Isabella4 wrote: I had my 1st MRI a week ago, and hated it....BUT ...it IS doable.  Go for it. I had them pull me out after I'd got in 18", just panicked. I saw the sides and roof  of the cylinder sooo near to me, I had to put on a blindfold, and went for it ....not the best experience I have ever had, said I wouldn't do it ever again, but now, a week later, I am pretty sure I could do it !! Be aware that the noise is terrific, like someone banging away on a very large piece of scaffolding pole. The bangs come in sequences of 8's and 10's, while it sounds as if there is a washer on 'spin' right next to your ear !! Goodness knows why its so noisy, They put me earphones on, said to me 'listen to the music'- ha ha- how stupid did they think I was? I couldn't hear a thing for the racket!! I really don't think I have ever heard so much noise right next to me, but, as I said, I think I would go again. Isabella.
Posts.Title: CHICKEND OUT ON MRI gegfl SuziQ422

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 06:32AM Isabella4 wrote: My first tube came out at 3 days, while still in hospital from bilat. My second was a pig....it just would not stop. It was supposed to be out at 25cc, but it took FOUR months to reach this, by which time it had grown in. I went to my GPs surgery, 3 of them had a go, and couldn't shift it. I had to go in to hospital and have a general anaesthetic to get it out. I hope never again to repeat this !! It is nearly 5 years ago and the little hole, under my arm still weeps, not much, but some days it can seep thru my tshirt. Isabella.
